Tallulah Falls History

In the 1820s, the first European trappers began to make their way into the Northeast Georgia area. While the Cherokee viewed the falls with trepidation and largely avoided the area, white settlers and travelers were enthralled by the awe-inspiring beauty of the falls and gorge and began sharing their experience in newspapers and travel books. Some visitors even compared Tallulah Falls to other legendary cascades, and soon Tallulah was being dubbed the “Niagara of the South.”

Where the Tallulah River made its magnificent drop into Tallulah Gorge, travelers made this area into a destination known far and wide as one of the most beautiful areas of the Eastern United States. The coming of the railroad in the late 19th century made this town a more accessible tourist mecca. Rufus Lafayette Moss, one of the men responsible for bringing the railroad to town, was also one of the founding commissioners of Tallulah Falls when it was first incorporated in 1885.

 

[Show thumbnails]

Even before the Cherokee, the magnificence of the Tallulah Gorge has captivated all who have stood on its shoulders. To the first tribes, it was an impassable chasm that struck fear into their lore. Stories of Little People that would trick or push unwary travelers over the edge, or legends of forlorn lovers visiting the cliffs in hopes of joining their lost love in the next life can be found scattered like tantalizing crumbs throughout the history of different tribes from this area.

To the first Europeans venturing into this land, the Tallulah Gorge became a spectacle to behold. It didn’t take long for people from Atlanta to be lured to the beauty of the Gorge, and to many, this region of Northeast Georgia became a respite from the oppressive summer heat of the big city. The area became known as the place where “Springtime spends the Summer”, and Rabun County still wears this description with pride.

Named after the five falls that cascade through the Gorge carved by the Tallulah River, visitors from outside the area first discovered the falls in 1819. Some of the earliest visitors include: Vice President John C. Calhoun in 1829 and John Howard Payne, author of “Home Sweet Home” in 1835. Joseph LeConte, one of the founders of the Sierra Club made numerous visits. By 1835, visitation of the falls had grown enough that a local resident began offering lodging and food to travelers.  Although only a rough cabin, the Tallulah Hotel officially opened in 1840. Recognizing the value of the gorge, and being a consummate outdoorsman, in 1882 Mr. Rufus Moss orchestrated the bringing the Tallulah Falls Railroad to the Northeast Georgia Mountains, and the tourism boomed. In its heyday, Tallulah Falls boasted seventeen hotels and boarding houses in and around the town.

Referred to as the Niagara of the South, there was much to do in addition to viewing the falls. The hotels rented horses, offered billiards, tennis, wide hammocks, and rocking chairs for front porch relaxation. At night the air was filled with music for dancing in the major hotels. On July 24, 1886, Professor Leon was the first known to cross the Gorge on a high wire, a feat that was repeated by Karl Wallenda on July 18, 1970.

After the Georgia Railway and Electric Company merged to form the Georgia Railway and Power Company, a series of dams were begun in 1912 to harness the raging power of the Tallulah River. In September, 1913, electricity was being sent from Tallulah Falls to Atlanta. Tallulah Falls has also had its share of tragedy. In December 1921, a fire that burned for days devastated the town. The fire destroyed stores, hotels, and many homes. Very little that was destroyed was rebuilt. In ruins today, the Glenbrook Hotel is the only hotel that is still standing from that grand era.

Tourism began to fade, and when the railroad was closed in 1961, Tallulah Falls’ future seemed uncertain. However, today, large numbers of visitors are again coming to view the splendor of the Gorge.  Here they discover a variety of delights. There is fishing and boating on three different lakes with in the town limits; hiking on several trails at Tallulah Gorge State Park; a seven mile mountain bike trail in the park, plus forest service roads;  rock climbing in the Gorge (by permit only); swimming at Terrora Beach and picnicking on the grounds of Tallulah Gorge State Park. On Saturday night, during Spring, Summer, and Fall, musicians gather on Bluegrass Square on main street for open jam sessions. Free to the public, Saturday Night Bluegrass serves hot-dogs and cokes for donation.

Caressed by the Northeast corner of the North Georgia Mountains, Tallulah Falls is conveniently located on Highway 441, an hour and a half northeast of Atlanta. To find us, take I-85 North to I-985 North. I-985 ends North of Gainesville, but US Highway 23 continues until it merges with US 441 / GA 15 near Cornelia. Continue following US 23 / GA 15 / US 441 and Tallulah Falls will be eight miles north of Hollywood and twelve miles south of Clayton.

Though the falls may not be as spectacular as they once were, scheduled water releases throughout the year restore the flow for a few days at a time attracting large numbers of visitors. In addition, the beautiful Tallulah Gorge State Park, a joint venture between Georgia Power Company and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, has been added with a learning center that features the natural history of Tallulah Gorge.

CVE-2018-15919.summary: Remotely observable behaviour in auth-gss2.c in OpenSSH through 7.8 could be used by remote attackers to detect existence of users on a target system when GSS2 is in use. NOTE: the discoverer states 'We understand that the OpenSSH developers do not want to treat such a username enumeration (or "oracle") as a vulnerability.'

CVE-2017-15906.summary: The process_open function in sftp-server.c in OpenSSH before 7.6 does not properly prevent write operations in readonly mode, which allows attackers to create zero-length files.
